items.title: 5.1.0: tox warnings
items.body:

```

items.title: ImmutableDeclaration: Allows mutable _v_attrs
items.body:
Some user code likes to assign to `_v_attrs` and/or write into the dictionary to piggyback on caching. Since ImmutableDeclaration provides no way to clear `_v_attrs` (it assumes it stays None), this can lead to incorrect results. 

This is not a regression in 5.0 but a pre-existing problem.

Proposal: Make `ImmutableDeclaration` use a property to always return a fresh dictionary for `_v_attrs`.

items.title: `providedBy()` swallows all exceptions accessing `ob.__providedBy__`
items.body:
And then has a fallback that ignores it. This makes it very hard to debug issues with descriptors, including issues that result in inconsistent IROs. The reasons it does this are unknown, but may have to do with (security) proxies and/or ease of C implementation.

At the very least, `providedBy` should whitelist the IRO exception and let it propagate.

Ideally, there would be a small set of exceptions it catches leaving everything else to propagate.

Problem found in https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.container/issues/34

cf #163

items.title: Can `@implementer` only add an interface if not implemented already?
items.body:
Currently it always does. There's some small bits of logic to re-order interfaces given at the same time to avoid the more egregious ways it would produce invalid resolution orders, but it doesn't pay attention to inheritance. This makes it easy to produce invalid orders if a sub-class redeclares something implemented by a superclass.

Alternately, what about a new decorator that does that?

See https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.formlib/pull/31#discussion_r400368942 for more context.

items.title: Regression: Objects with no declared interfaces used to implement Interface
items.body:
In 5.0.x, the `_empty` `_ImmutableDeclaration` object does not include `Interface`, whereas in 4.7 `_empty` did. This breaks looking up adapter registrations for `Interface` if the provided object does not otherwise implement any interfaces. This includes things like:

- Instances of direct subclasses of `object`;
- (Python 2) Old style classes (not their instances).

See https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.traversing/issues/14 for a practical failure.

items.title: ZOPE_INTERFACE_STRICT_IRO is actually ZOPE_INTERFACE_STRICT_RO
items.body: The former is documented and used in user warnings, but the latter is what's actually used.

items.title: Inconsistent RO for InterfaceClass
items.body: Noticed while working on https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.schema/issues/80. It's an easy fix.

items.title: Interface.get/queryTaggedValue should respect __iro__, not just __bases__
items.body:
Consider this inheritance tree:
```python
        O = Interface
        class F(O):
            taggedValue('tag', 'F')
            tag = Attribute('F')
        class E(O):
            taggedValue('tag', 'E')            
            tag = Attribute('E')
        class D(O):
            taggedValue('tag', 'D')            
            tag = Attribute('D')
        class C(D, F):
            taggedValue('tag', 'C')            
            tag = Attribute('C')
        class B(D, E):
            pass
        class A(B, C):
            pass
```

If we then look at the tagged value `"tag"` and the `tag`  Attribute of `A`, we get two different answers:

```pycon
>>> A['tag'].__name__
'C'
>>> A.getTaggedValue('tag')
'D'
```

This is because looking up tagged values only uses `__bases__`, whereas finding attributes follows the `__iro__`:
```pycon
>>> A.__iro__
(<InterfaceClass __main__.A>,
 <InterfaceClass __main__.B>,
 <InterfaceClass __main__.C>,
 <InterfaceClass __main__.D>,
 <InterfaceClass __main__.E>,
 <InterfaceClass __main__.F>,
 <InterfaceClass zope.interface.Interface>)
```

To implement this, much like there exists `InterfaceClass.direct(name)`, there should probably exist `InterfaceClass.queryDirectTaggedValue(name)`. 

Other `Direct` methods, like `getDirectTaggedValueTags` might be nice (though I don't have a direct use case for them right now).

items.title: lookup and hash is slow
items.body:
This performance problem bugs me since a while and some optimization was already done by me, primary in `InterfaceClass`.

I took the long-running and intense component-architecture using Plone tests as a measure here.
I took Py-Spy to get numbers by letting it sample for ~100s. The "Own-Time" of a function or line is here of interest: Where is time wasted?

Two functions always in the top 5 are `zope.interface.interface._lookup` and `zope.interface.interface.InterfaceClass.__hash__`. Both together take with: 
- zope.interface 4.7.1 about 17%
- zope.interface master about 11% 

of the test time.

For `__hash__` I looked into the code. It is primary in there, because if `__eq__` is implemented `__hash__` needs also to be implemented. Just, our `__eq__` does not use the `__hash__` (which is fine. 

Our current `__hash__` hashes the tuple of name and module. To be sortable it would need to be swapped anyway. 

So what if the `InterfaceClass.__hash__` uses  the very fast `object.__hash__`?

I tried this and it breaks one test in zope.interface. And I question if this test makes sense at all.
I'll prepare a PR to discuss it. 
I used it with the Plone tests and nothing breaks so far.

**The combined time of `_lookup` and `__hash__` shrinks to about 5%** 

I created Plone site and added content, restarted Zope: all fine.

So, its doubles the speed compared to the current state.

For `_lookup` I have no further ideas to optimize. Maybe by shifting this over to C-code? But I would keep this for a different discussion.

I really appreciate feedback here.

items.title: verify[Object|Class] should report all errors found
items.body: It's painful to work through errors one at a time when all errors could be reported at once.

While looking at #118, I noticed that the error message produced is quite strangely formatted:

```
BrokenMethodImplementation: The implementation of pop violates its contract
        because implementation requires too many arguments.
```

This comes down to the use of a multi-line string literal in `__str__`: https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.interface/blob/0048a56bac299db7c78a9c8e52c5928e4ec06f38/src/zope/interface/exceptions.py#L64-L67

items.title: C/Python impl difference: C impl of IFoo.__call__ swallows *all* exceptions accessing __conform__
items.body:
While investigating #162, I found a discrepancy in the C and Python implementations of `InterfaceBase.__call__`. In C, if accessing the `__conform__` attribute returns NULL, meaning an exception was raised, we ignore it (call `PyErr_Clear`) and continue on. In the Python version, though, we just use `getattr(obj, '__conform__', None)`. In Python 3, that only catches AttributeError.

This matters because of things like Acquisition which can raise strange exceptions. In particular, the test cases for `five.intid` have a setup that with a cycle in the acquisition path. That raises a `RuntimeError` (at least with the Python implementation) and the test fails with the `RuntimeError`, instead of continuing with the normal adapter lookup.

Ideally, the C implementation wouldn't be catching and discarding arbitrary exceptions (`MemoryError`, `KeyboardInterrupt`, etc), but that ship has probably sailed. So probably the best bet is to make the Python implementation also catch all exceptions. Sigh.

items.title: `_empty` singleton is mutable
items.body:
zope.interface.declarations returns a global `_empty` Declaration object in a few cases. But this object is fully mutable: its bases can be set, it can be subscribed and have dependents added. That doesn't seem safe for a global object. 

Can we either:

- Stop returning a global object from these APIs (return a new object); or 
- introduce a special subclass that's truly immutable (prohibits changing bases, adding dependents, etc).

items.title: Remove support for "hashing" uninitialized interfaces
items.body:
Since [this commit in 2011](https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.interface/commit/05a899a8275bbd6b2e332a4fbfeab4d7e1dc40f8) (zope.interface 3.6.5) we've been emitting a warning if a buggy subclass of `InterfaceClass` attempted to hash itself before completing its initialization. In the [original bug report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/811792) this was identified to be a bug in the third-party module that was doing this. Because it had a release scheduled soon and because of the vagaries of downstream packaging schedules, @tseaver added the current behaviour to workaround the issue. 

But the current behaviour is not ideal; in addition to the warning it can lead to objects not being found when their hash changes, and of course there's the warning being printed. Plus, with #156, the fallback behaviour got even uglier.

We've been emitting a warning for more than 8 years. The only test in this repo that depends on the behaviour is one that specifically invokes it. 

I hope we can drop the fallback.

items.title: Can/Should we define __all__ for modules?
items.body: Because of the dual implementation in C and Python, and the various backwards compatibility phrasings, there's some extra cruft in many of the modules. Defining `__all__` would help clarify expected usage. See https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.interface/pull/151#discussion_r369525607

items.title: list(ProxyFactory(schema)) does not work on Python 3
items.body:
This code works on Python 2.7:

```pycon
>>> from zope.interface import Interface
>>> from zope.security.proxy import ProxyFactory
>>> class IFoo(Interface):
...     def x(): 'an method'
...
>>> list(IFoo)
['x']
>>> list(ProxyFactory(IFoo))
['x']
```

It breaks on Python 3:

```pycon
>>> list(IFoo)
['x']
>>> list(ProxyFactory(IFoo))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
zope.security.interfaces.ForbiddenAttribute: ('__len__', <InterfaceClass __main__.IFoo>)
```

AFAICT the reason is that Python's `list(an_object)` tries to compute `len(an_object)` as an optimization (to preallocate all the list entries in one go).  Python 2 ignores exceptions raised by `an_object.__class__.__len__(an_object)` when they're an AttributeError subclass and merely skips the optimization.  Python 3 does not suppress the exception but instead fails the entire operation.

It's a bit more subtle than that, e.g. if a class doesn't have a `__len__`, then list() on instances of that class succeeds, but if the class has a `__len__` that does `raise AttributeError`, then list() on instances of that class fails (on Python 3).

I'm not sure if this is a problem in zope.interface or in zope.security.  The simplest solution would be to allow `__len__` on Interface objects.

items.title: Can we hook zope.interface.common up to standard library ABCs/classes?
items.body:
`z.i.common.idatetime` declares appropriate `classImplements` for various stdlib classes, and the same with the exceptions in `z.i.common.interfaces`. However, `z.i.c.mapping` and `z.i.c.sequences` do not. Also, there are some things missing, such as `IBytes` and `IText` and `INumber`.

Given the existence of abstract base classes that essentially define these same interfaces, is there something we can do to ease the gap by default? In the past I've used [dolmen.builtins](https://pypi.org/project/dolmen.builtins/) for some of this.

Question is inspired by [this post of glyph](https://glyph.twistedmatrix.com/2009/02/explaining-why-interfaces-are-great.html):

> One of the irritating things about using zope.interface is that the metadata about standard objects in zope.interface.common is not hooked up to anything: IMapping.providedBy({}) returns False.  ABCs will provide that metadata in the standard library, making zope.interface that much more useful once it has been upgraded to understand the declarations that the collections and numbers modules provide.

items.title: Documentation bug: subscription delivery order
items.body:
"https://zopeinterface.readthedocs.io/en/latest/" states in section "subscriptions":

> Subscribers defined for less general required interfaces are returned before subscribers for more general interfaces.

This contraticts the example preceding this quote where the subscription for `None` (the most general interface) is delivered before the subscription for  (the less general interface) `IRequire1`.

In addition, the documentation is not yet Python 3 compatible.

items.title: names() implementation contradicts documentation in Python 3
items.body:
There's something I noticed while porting some code to Python 3. The implementation of names() in InterfaceClass doesn't return a sequence, as the documentation states, but a dict view.
To me this seems weird – have a function return two different types that don't represent the same way/idea of working with the data underneath it. 
How do we proceed with this?
I'd prefer to return a list, even if we don't take advantage of the new dict behaviour, because this would be a breaking change in the API.

https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.interface/blob/3042b9fa7c37aa0d0b61efcdb0b1a436fef9bf59/src/zope/interface/interface.py#L389-L399

items.title: BrokenMethodImplementation "doesn't allow enough arguments" error when using staticmethods on Python 3
items.body:
Verifying a class using `@provider` behaves differently on Python 2.7 vs. Python 3.7 with zope.interface 4.5.0:

```python
import zope.interface
from zope.interface.verify import verifyObject

class IFoo(zope.interface.Interface):
    def bar(a, b):
        pass

@zope.interface.provider(IFoo)
class Foo(object):
    @staticmethod
    def bar(a, b):
        pass

assert verifyObject(IFoo, Foo)
```

On Python 2.7, this code passes. On Python 3.7 it raises a `BrokenMethodImplementation`:

```pytb
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/andy/test/.tox/py37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/zope/interface/verify.py", line 105, in verifyObject
    return _verify(iface, candidate, tentative, vtype='o')
  File "/Users/andy/test/.tox/py37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/zope/interface/verify.py", line 97, in _verify
    raise BrokenMethodImplementation(name, mess)
zope.interface.exceptions.BrokenMethodImplementation: The implementation of bar violates its contract
        because implementation doesn't allow enough arguments.
```

items.title: Replacement of cp27my 4.5.0 on pypi
items.body: The SHAs on `zope.interface-4.5.0-cp27-cp27mu-manylinux1_x86_64.whl` changed last week and I am checking that this is intended. It broke our builds and replacement of packages 6 month after release smelled slightly suspect to me.

Interestingly, the difference is probably in the fact that 4.4.3 has a wheel and 4.5.0 comes as a source distribution only. I've poked inside pip and looks like the failure with the tgz is when pip tries to extract version information from the filename `zope.interface-4.5.0` it tries to find the canonical name, `zope-interface`, and fails thus marking the package as "Missing project version".

items.title: cannot create an IDict interface that passes verifyObject on cpython and pypy
Ease Python 3 porting
items.body:
There are quite some packages in Plone that are broken because of these and similar lines:
https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.interface/blob/c1b436de3f36bb533634b3287a601cd81b63ccb2/src/zope/interface/adapter.py#L327-L328
In many cases the quick fix is just to redefine `name=str(name)`.

To ease the porting process I would modify them to something like:

```
if not isinstance(name, STRING_TYPES):
     try:
          name = str(name)
          log.warning('name is not a string which is a deprecated behavior')
    except:
          raise ValueError('name should be a string') 
```

items.title: Sync namespace packages approach
items.body:
Hello.

As mentioned in Python docs [0]:
> **Every** distribution that uses the namespace package must include an identical `__init__.py`. If any distribution does not, it will cause the namespace logic to fail and the other sub-packages will not be importable. Any additional code in `__init__.py` will be inaccessible.

but it seems that zope.deprecation [1] and zope.configuration [2] have different content in namespace `__init__.py` files than zope.interface.

It would be nice to sync namespace `__init__.py` files across modules maintained by Zope foundation so they will be installable in parallel.

[0] https://packaging.python.org/guides/packaging-namespace-packages/#pkg-resources-style-namespace-packages
[1] https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.deprecation/blob/master/src/zope/__init__.py
[2] https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.configuration/blob/master/src/zope/__init__.py

Possibly related to:
* https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.interface/issues/107
* https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.interface/issues/68
* https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.interface/issues/97

items.title: 4.4.1 Regression: `Components._utilities`/`_utility_registrations` can get out of sync with the cache
items.body:
The `_UtilityRegistrations` object makes a reference to the `Component`'s `_utilities` and `_utility_registrations` when it is created. The `Component` object holds a strong reference to the `_UtilityRegistrations`. Presumably the `_UtilityRegistrations` holds these two references to avoid holding a reference to the `Component` instance and thus introducing a cycle.

The problem introduced in 4.4.1 is that if either of those two instance variables are assigned to, the cache object is not updated. Previously, accessing the cache would compare the identity of the objects it held with the identity of the objects the Component held and reset if they changed. Now that doesn't happen.

The use case is that subclasses may want to change the identity of `_utility_registrations` in the `registerUtility` method. Specifically, we have a subclass that will change the `_utility_registrations` object to a BTree instead of a dict when it grows to a certain size.

Now we *could* update our subclass to have a dependency on >= 4.4.1 and knowledge of the fact that the cache is now an instance attribute that also needs to be updated, but I'd prefer to see it handled here so that the cache is always consistent and guaranteed to be so.

items.title: 4.4.1 breaks pickling of PersistentComponents that have registrations
items.body:
I [figured out what I was worried about](https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.interface/pull/84#discussion_r116334080) in regards to #84.

The changes in 4.4.1 break the tests for zc.catalog (but it should be very simple to reproduce outside of those tests). All versions of Python now fail with a variation on this error:
```
  File "<doctest extentcatalog.rst[23]>", line 1, in <module>
    root = makeRoot()
  File "<doctest extentcatalog.rst[13]>", line 12, in makeRoot
    transaction.commit()
...
  File "//py27/lib/python2.7/site-
    return self._dump(meta, obj.__getstate__())
  File "//py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ZODB/serialize.py", line 428, in _dump
    self._p.dump(state)
  File "//.tox/py27/bin/../lib/python2.7/copy_reg.py", line 70, in _reduce_ex
    raise TypeError, "can't pickle %s objects" % base.__name__
TypeError: can't pickle function objects
```

Or `_pickle.PicklingError: Can't pickle <class 'function'>: attribute lookup builtins.function failed`.

Coercing Python 3 to use the Python implementation of ZODB pickle gets us a better error message:
```
  File "//py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/zodbpickle/pickle_3.py", line 694, in save_global
    (obj, module, name))
_pickle.PicklingError: Can't pickle <function _UtilityRegistrations.__init__.<locals>.<lambda> at 0x11073c598>: it's not found as zope.interface.registry.<lambda>
```

Debugging the error shows that `state` is `{'data': {'components': <PersistentComponents>}}`, and further debugging shows that we're trying to pickle `PersistentComponents.__dict__`, leading to this error:

```
(Pdb) pp state
{'data': {'components': <PersistentComponents >}}
(Pdb) pp self._p.memo.copy()[id(state['data']['components'].__dict__)]
(7,
 {'__bases__': (<BaseGlobalComponents base>,),
  '__name__': '',
  '_adapter_registrations': {},
  '_handler_registrations': [],
  '_subscription_registrations': [],
  '_utility_registrations': {(<InterfaceClass zope.intid.interfaces.IIntIds>, ''): (<zope.intid.IntIds object at 0x10a9c42e8>,
                                                                                    '',
                                                                                    None)},
  '_v_utility_registrations_cache': <zope.interface.registry._UtilityRegistrations object at 0x10a9d6ac8>,
  'adapters': <zope.component.persistentregistry.PersistentAdapterRegistry object at 0x10a972eb8>,
  'utilities': <zope.component.persistentregistry.PersistentAdapterRegistry object at 0x10a9c40b8>})
```

The `makeRoot` function is very simple:
```pycon
>>> def makeRoot():
...     db = DB()
...     conn = db.open()
...     root = conn.root()
...     site_manager = root['components'] = (
...         zope.component.persistentregistry.PersistentComponents())
...     site_manager.__bases__ = (zope.component.getGlobalSiteManager(),)
...     site_manager.registerUtility(
...         zope.intid.IntIds(family=btrees_family),
...         provided=zope.intid.interfaces.IIntIds)
...     setSiteManager(site_manager)
...     transaction.commit()
...     return root
```

Reverting any tested python to zope.interface 4.4.0 fixes the problem.

The problem is that `PersistentComponents` *isn't* actually a `Persistent` object; only its `.adapters` and `.utilities` are, so the magic that's supposed to elide `_v` attributes never happens:

```python
class PersistentComponents(Components):

    def _init_registries(self):
        self.adapters = PersistentAdapterRegistry()
        self.utilities = PersistentAdapterRegistry()
```

Suggestions on how to tackle this?

items.title: Leak in tests having persistent registries due to caching in zope.interface.registry._UtilityRegistrations
items.body: Standard test cleanup doesn't deal with the cache.  It wouldn't be sufficient to simply have zope.interface.registry.Components.__init__ clear it's own cache entry, because there may be entries for persistent registries that need to be dealt with too.

items.title: document the zope.interface.registry.Components component registry
items.body:
The `Components` class has no clear documentation within `zope.interface`. The closest I can find is the `AdapterRegistry` but that misses several aspects of the `Components` class. This is, of course, because the `Components` class is higher level than the `AdapterRegistry` despite having a very similar API.

Ideally this would include examples or explanation of why you would use `Components` instead of `AdapterRegistry` as well as exposing the `IComponents`, `IComponentLookup` and `IComponentRegistry` interfaces.

Related: #41

items.title: zope.interface 4.3.3 causes warning in valgrind
items.body:
The following occurs when running valgrind on a python script that loads zope.interface 4.3.3 but not zope.interface 4.3.2.

==13973== Warning: DWARF2 reader: Badly formed extended line op encountered

Tested on valgrind 3.10.1 and 3.12.  zope.interface 4.3.3 causes valgrind 3.10.1 to log the warning then crash, but valgrind 3.12 logs it as a warning and continues execution.

zope.interface installed via continuum public defaults conda repository.  Running xubuntu 14.04 with conda 4.2.13 and python 2.7.11.

items.title: Missing __init__.py warning when importing pkg_resources
items.body:
Hi. I found that a very simple script can emit an annoying warning about zope.interface. Type this in an empty directory:
``` bash
python2 -m virtualenv env
./env/bin/pip install zope.interface
./env/bin/python -Werror -c "import pkg_resources"
```
The warning produced is:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "./env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 3019, in <module>
    @_call_aside
  File "./env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 3003, in _call_aside
    f(*args, **kwargs)
  File "./env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 3047, in _initialize_master_working_set
    for dist in working_set
  File "./env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 3047, in <genexpr>
    for dist in working_set
  File "./env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2577, in activate
    declare_namespace(pkg)
  File "./env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2151, in declare_namespace
    _handle_ns(packageName, path_item)
  File "./env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2071, in _handle_ns
    loader = importer.find_module(packageName)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/pkgutil.py", line 186, in find_module
    file, filename, etc = imp.find_module(subname, path)
ImportWarning: Not importing directory './env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zope': missing __init__.py
```
It is still effective with the current github code `./env/bin/pip install git+https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.interface.git `

It is a very annoying message since on my django project, it represents 90% of the warnings emitted when I launch my unit tests.

I have tested this with python 2.7.12 and python 3.5.2.

If we change the import to zope.interface._zope_interface_coptimizations it works.

items.title: test_sorting.py fail
items.body:
When I run test_sorting.py, it fails with message as below.

```
FAIL: test_w_equal_names (__main__.Test)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "src/zope/interface/tests/test_sorting.py", line 47, in test_w_equal_names
    self.assertEqual(l, [m1_I1, I1])
AssertionError: Lists differ: [<InterfaceClass __main__.I1>,... != [<InterfaceClass zope.interfac...
```

I printed the interface modules and they are `__main__` and zope.interface.tests.m1. It looks to me that `__main__` should be before zope.interface.tests.m1, which means I1 should be before m1_I1 when sorting completes. So I wonder how does a successful test work?

items.title: Components.register/unregisterUtility is slow (linear with size of all registrations)
items.body:
We've noticed that as a component registry gets larger, the time taken to add or remove utilities increases with the total number of all utility registrations. It doesn't take very many utilities to make registering and unregistering a painfully slow process.

Here's some pseudo-code that demonstrates, using IPython's `%time` magic to record how long it takes to register 1000 new utilities:

``` python
In [1]: import zope.interface.registry
In [2]: import zope.interface
In [3]: class IFoo(zope.interface.Interface): pass
In [5]: @zope.interface.implementer(IFoo)
   ...: class Foo(object): pass
   ...:
In [6]: reg = zope.interface.registry.Registry()
In [16]: def add_to_reg(reg, count):
    ...:     for _ in range(count):
    ...:         comp = Foo()
    ...:         reg.registerUtility(component=comp, name=str(id(comp)))
In [12]: %time add_to_reg(reg, 1000)
CPU times: user 785 ms, sys: 7.23 ms, total: 792 ms
Wall time: 810 ms

In [17]: %time add_to_reg(reg, 1000)
CPU times: user 2.32 s, sys: 19.1 ms, total: 2.34 s
Wall time: 2.4 s

In [18]: %time add_to_reg(reg, 1000)
CPU times: user 3.92 s, sys: 28.8 ms, total: 3.95 s
Wall time: 4.05 s

In [19]: %time add_to_reg(reg, 1000)
CPU times: user 5.57 s, sys: 41.1 ms, total: 5.61 s
Wall time: 5.76 s

In [20]: %time add_to_reg(reg, 1000)
CPU times: user 7.29 s, sys: 55.7 ms, total: 7.34 s
Wall time: 7.53 s
```

In other words, by the time there are 5,000 objects in the registry, adding a new utility takes 72ms. And it just keeps growing.

The culprit is in checking whether or not the component is already subscribed. This is a linear process that looks at every entry in the `_utility_registrations` dict (likewise for unregister):

``` python
def registerUtility(...):
         ...
        subscribed = False
        for ((p, _), data) in iter(self._utility_registrations.items()):
            if p == provided and data[0] == component:
                subscribed = True
                break

        self._utility_registrations[(provided, name)] = component, info, factory
        self.utilities.register((), provided, name, component)

        if not subscribed:
            self.utilities.subscribe((), provided, component)
```

If we could safely assume that all the `components` are hashable, we could substantially optimize this by using an auxilliary dictionary (keyed on _just_ `provided`) and a `set` of components. Something like this:

``` python
    @property
    def _v_utility_opt(self):
        if '_v_utility_opt' in self.__dict__:
            return self.__dict__['_v_utility_opt']
        from collections import defaultdict
        opt = defaultdict(set)
        for ((p, _), data) in iter(self._utility_registrations.items()):
            opt[p].add(data[0])
        self.__dict__['_v_utility_opt'] = opt
        return opt

    def _subscribed(self, provided, component):
        return component in self._v_utility_opt[provided]

    def registerUtility(self, component=None, provided=None, name=_u(''),
                        info=_u(''), event=True, factory=None):
        ...
        subscribed = self._subscribed(provided, component)

        self._utility_registrations[(provided, name)] = component, info, factory
        self._v_utility_opt[provided].add(component)
        self.utilities.register((), provided, name, component)

        if not subscribed:
            self.utilities.subscribe((), provided, component)
```

That makes adding and removing O(1) and nearly independent of the size of the components registered:

``` python
In [25]: reg = zope.interface.registry.Components()

In [26]: %time add_to_reg(reg, 1000)
CPU times: user 53.7 ms, sys: 1.49 ms, total: 55.2 ms
Wall time: 54.6 ms

In [27]: %time add_to_reg(reg, 1000)
CPU times: user 57.5 ms, sys: 1.57 ms, total: 59.1 ms
Wall time: 58.8 ms

In [28]: %time add_to_reg(reg, 1000)
CPU times: user 79.5 ms, sys: 1.84 ms, total: 81.4 ms
Wall time: 81.1 ms

In [29]: %time add_to_reg(reg, 1000)
CPU times: user 72.8 ms, sys: 1.79 ms, total: 74.6 ms
Wall time: 74.2 ms

In [30]: %time add_to_reg(reg, 1000)
CPU times: user 73 ms, sys: 1.12 ms, total: 74.1 ms
Wall time: 74.2 ms

In [31]: %time add_to_reg(reg, 1000)
CPU times: user 115 ms, sys: 5.19 ms, total: 120 ms
Wall time: 120 ms

In [32]: len(reg._utility_registrations)
Out[32]: 6000
```

(Much better. And imagine the effect it could have on startup time and testing time for large apps, independent of registering utilities at runtime.)

Is this something we can assume? Or is there some other way to make this process faster? Or am I missing something altogether?

If there's a consensus here, I'm happy to write the code (but it won't be for a week or so).

items.title: Make declarations.Implements (and possibly Provides) comparable?
items.body:
Recently we had the need to do some `IComponents`-like things on some very large persistent data sets. So we started with a subclass of `AdapterRegistry` and made it use BTrees instead of dicts. Everything works fine so long as you stay in the realm of interfaces, but as soon as you try to do something based on classes, like `components.registerAdapter(factory, provided=IFoo, required=(str,))`  you blow up with `TypeError: Object has default comparison`. 

Actually it's slightly worse than that. Some of the dicts used in the implementation of Components (which we also replaced with BTrees) use keys that are tuples. Tuples are automatically comparable, even if their elements aren't. But having non-comparable keys (or rather, keys that change across processes) is a sure way to corrupt the BTree.

I looked into it, and was pretty surprised to find that not only are `Implements` and `Provides` not comparable, they actually rely on the default, identity-based, `__hash__` and `__eq__` inherited from object. Everything pretty much happens to work out for a regular `PersistentAdapterRegistry` because of the way these objects are pickled (in Implement's case, via `__reduce__` and a call to `implementedBy`, which aggressively caches the same object, so identities stay the same in a single process even across pickling).

Is it a bad idea to make `Implements` comparable so it can be used in BTrees? To work for the `IComponents` use-case, it would have to be mutually-comparable with `InterfaceClass`, but it already has `__name__` and `__module__` (which is what `InterfaceClass` uses), so that might just work out nearly automatically.

If there's consensus this is a reasonable idea, I can work on a PR. (In our particular use-case, we were able to simply prohibit class-based registrations as they don't occur in our data set.)

items.title: Document AdapterRegistry inside the API docs
items.body:
AdapterRegistry is documented in the narrative docs at https://docs.zope.org/zope.interface/adapter.html 

but it is not documented as part of the API page https://docs.zope.org/zope.interface/api.html

It would be nice to have it documented in the API so that external documentation can link to it using inter-sphinx links.

For example in Twisted `L{zope.interface.adapter.AdapterRegistry}` is used to create a link from Twisted API docs to zope.interface API docs ... but the link resolution fails. 

 `L{zope.interface.declarations.implementer}` works as it is documented on the API page.

See  https://github.com/twisted/twisted/pull/238

Thanks!

items.title: please build wheels instead of eggs for binary distribution on win32
items.body:
Pip can't install binary eggs, but it can install wheels.

This should be as simple as `python setup.py bdist_wheel; twine upload dist/*`.

items.title: Interface comparison with emtpy __name__ reports incorrect equality
items.body:
When comparing two different interfaces with the same, empty name they are reported to be equal:

zope.interface version 4.1.3:

```
>>> from zope.interface import Interface
>>> class A(Interface): pass
... 
>>> class B(Interface): pass
... 
>>> A == B  # correctly repots unquality
False

>>> A.__name__ = ''
>>> B.__name__ = ''
>>> A == B  # equality looks incorrect to me.
True
```

With zope.interface 3.6.7 the last test returns `False`, so they are treated as unequal.

Also, the `zope.interface.interface.InterfaceClass.__cmp` function comment says ( https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.interface/blob/master/src/zope/interface/interface.py#L490 )

```
        # Yes, I did mean to name this __cmp, rather than __cmp__.
        # It is a private method used by __lt__ and __gt__.
        # I don't want to override __eq__ because I want the default
        # __eq__, which is really fast.
```

But the `__eq__` function was added with https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.interface/commit/c7a10ce52ad99fb6528416678fc057e5338d3e2b -- the comment should be changed.
Related: https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/570942

items.title: Installing zope.interface 4.1.3 via setuptools.setup eats all memory

items.title: pip install zope.interface fails on Python 3.5 on Windows
items.body:
`pip install zope.interface` on Python 3.5 on Windows fails:

```

items.title: Broken interface definition for IComponentRegistry.unregisteredAdapter
items.body:
(Moved to `zope.interface` from https://github.com/zopefoundation/zope.component/issues/5, because the interface now lives in `zope.interface.interfaces`).

In https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.component/+bug/158580, @zopyx reported:

> `zope/component/interfaces.py` contains this for `unregisterAdaper()` which is appearently wrong (seems to be the same docstring as for `registerAdapter()`)

``` python
def unregisterAdapter(factory=None, required=None,
                          provided=None, name=u''):
        """Register an adapter factory

        A boolean is returned indicating whether the registry was
        changed. If the given component is None and there is no
        component registered, or if the given component is not
        None and is not registered, then the function returns
        False, otherwise it returns True.

        Parameters:

        factory
            This is the object used to compute the adapter. The
            factory can be None, in which case any factory
            registered to implement the given provided interface
            for the given required specifications with the given
            name is unregistered.

        required
            This is a sequence of specifications for objects to be
            adapted. If the factory is not None and the required
            arguments is omitted, then the value of the factory's
            __component_adapts__ attribute will be used. The
            __component_adapts__ attribute attribute is normally
            set in class definitions using adapts function, or for
            callables using the adapter decorator. If the factory
            is None or doesn't have a __component_adapts__ adapts
            attribute, then this argument is required.

        provided
            This is the interface provided by the adapter and
            implemented by the factory. If the factory is not
            None and implements a single interface, then this
            argument is optional and the factory-implemented
            interface will be used.

        name
            The adapter name.

        An Unregistered event is generated with an IAdapterRegistration.
```

items.title: Inconsistent resolution order
items.body:
This best explained with the code below:

``` python
from zope.interface import Interface

def factory(O):
    class F(O): pass
    class E(O): pass
    class D(O): pass
    class C(D, F): pass
    class B(D, E): pass
    class A(B, C): pass
    return A

mro = [x.__name__ for x in factory(object).__mro__]
iro = [x.__name__ for x in factory(Interface).__iro__]
print('MRO', mro)
print('IRO', iro)
```

This code prints

``` python
MRO ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D', 'E', 'F', 'object']
IRO ['A', 'B', 'E', 'C', 'D', 'F', 'Interface']
```

You can see the inconsistency here, and mro is calculated correctly, of course.

```
$ pip freeze | grep zope
zope.interface==4.1.2
$ python --version
3.4.2
```

I tested on python 2.6.6 and got the same result.

items.title: Normal metaclass resolution not applied to InterfaceClass
items.body:
In https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/791218, @lrowe reported:

> While experimenting with my InterfaceClass subclass I noticed that it was only being used when it was specified as the first of the bases. I believe this is because InterfaceClass is not a subclass of `type`, so the normal metaclass derivation logic is not applied. The branch at svn+ssh://svn.zope.org/repos/main/zope.interface/branches/elro-metaclass-resolution implements that logic in `InterfaceClass.__new__`, picking from the base metaclasses that metaclass which subclasses all other base metaclasses.
> 
> The motivating factor here is: I need an Interface with a hook that gets called after `InterfaceClass.__init__` to allow for:
> - Checking that field names supplied as tagged values from directives correspond to actual field names to detect typos.
> - Registering the `Interface` instance for further configuration to be executed by a zope.configuration action.
> 
> Relevant changeset: http://zope3.pov.lt/trac/changeset/121497/zope.interface/branches/elro-metaclass-resolution
> 
> Example InterfaceClass subclass: http://dev.plone.org/plone/browser/plone.supermodel/branches/elro-directives/plone/supermodel/model.py#L58

items.title: Fix setup.py when using plain distutils
items.body:
In https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/629086, @zseil reported:

> Support for installing zope.interface with plain distutils has deteriorated a bit over the recent releases. There are currently two problems with the setup script - the list of packages is incomplete (reported as bug #611362) and the coptimization extension never gets built when not using setuptools. The attached patch fixes both problems for me. It also removes Python 2.3 support from the setup script, since zope.interface itself doesn't support that version anymore.
> 
> (Tested on Windows, Python 2.5 with a C compiler and Python 2.6 without a C compiler, in both cases without setuptools installed)

with patch:  https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/629086/+attachment/1537986/+files/distutils-compatibility.patch

items.title: W/o setuptools, "setup.py install" skips zope/interface/common/
items.body:
In https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/611362, @exarkun reported:

> After installing the 3.6.1 release from PyPI, the zope.interface.common package is not available:

```
exarkun@boson:~/Downloads$ tar xzf zope.interface-3.6.1.tar.gz
exarkun@boson:~/Downloads$ cd zope.interface-3.6.1/
exarkun@boson:~/Downloads/zope.interface-3.6.1$ python setup.py install --quiet --prefix /tmp/ZOPE-TEST
/usr/lib/python2.6/distutils/dist.py:266: UserWarning: Unknown distribution option: 'test_suite'
....
exarkun@boson:~/Downloads/zope.interface-3.6.1$ PYTHONPATH=/tmp/ZOPE-TEST/ python -c 'from zope.interface import common'
Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
ImportError: cannot import name common
exarkun@boson:~/Downloads/zope.interface-3.6.1$
```

and supplied a patch:

  https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/611362/+attachment/1471651/+files/setup.patch

I followed up:

> Hmm, this seems to be true only when installing without setuptools:

@glyph followed up:

> I just heard about a case of this happening on Ubuntu 12.10. I suspect it's a bug in setuptools or distutils or ubuntu's patching of same, not zope.interface; can someone comment on what mechanism ZI uses to include the 'common' package? I don't see it in setup.cfg, or a manifest file... I am guessing there's some setuptools magic which is supposed to make it get included.
> Also of note; setuptools _was_ installed on the system where this happened. It was zope.interface 4.0.3 in this case.

items.title: `unregisterAdapter` uses '==' while the underlying adapter registry uses 'is'
items.body:
In https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/551049, @mgedmin reported:

> Try this:

```
class MyTestClass(PlacelessSetUp):

    def _handler(self, event):
        print "Got event!"

    def test(self):
        sm = zope.component.getGlobalSiteManager()
        sm.registerHandler(self._handler, required=(zope.interface.Interface, ))
        assert sm.unregisterHandler(self._handler, required=(zope.interface.Interface, ))
        zope.event.notify(object())
```

> The assertion will demonstrate that the global site manager thinks it successfully unregistered the adapter, yet the subsequent notify() will invoke our handler.
> 
> Why? Because self._handler creates a new bound method instance every time you write that expression. sm.unregisterHandler compares it to the previously registered factory object using '==' which returns true. But then the site manager invokes zope.interface.adapter.BaseAdapterRegistry.unsubscribe, which uses 'is' for identity checking and therefore thinks it got a different handler.
> 
> zope.component should use the same kind of check as the underlying implementation, because it now lies to the programmer about unregistering an adapter that really remains registered.

@d03cc followed up:

> Trying to reproduce it, I noticed that the code that does not do the proper unregistration is in zope.interface and not in zope.component

items.title: `providedBy` does not respect `super`
items.body:
In https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/448712, Dieter Maurer reported:

> In some places, the implementation of a subclass adapter may take advantage of that defined for a base class. In such cases, "super" comes to mind. Unfortunately, "providedBy" (implicitely during in adapter lookup) does not respect "super" as shown by the folloging transscript:

```
>>> from zope.interface import Interface, implements
>>> class I1(Interface): pass
...
>>> class B(object): implements(Interface)
...
>>> class C(B): implements(I1)
...
>>> c=C()
>>> from zope.interface import providedBy
>>> list(providedBy(c))
[<InterfaceClass __main__.I1>, <InterfaceClass zope.interface.Interface>]
>>> list(providedBy(super(C,c)))
[<InterfaceClass __main__.I1>, <InterfaceClass zope.interface.Interface>]
```

items.title: 'unsubscribe' / 'unregister' leak persistent references
items.body:
In https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/330000, @ctheune  reports:

> See zope.interface.adapter.BaseAdapterRegistry. The methods `unregister` and `unsubscribe` leave the attributes `_adapters` and `_subscribers` with an interface reference in their dictionary key although the value indicates an empty value and thus the key could be removed.
> 
> For persistent registries this causes the database to reference interfaces even after all registrations for those interfaces have been removed.

> 
> Here's an example that provides the basis for a test case:

```pycon
>>> import zope.interface.interface
>>> class InterfaceClass(zope.interface.interface.InterfaceClass):
...     def __call__(self, *args):
...         print 'called', self, args
...
>>> IFoo = InterfaceClass('IFoo', (zope.interface.Interface,))
>>> IFoo(1)
called <InterfaceClass __main__.IFoo> (1,)
>>> class IBar(IFoo): pass
...
>>> IBar()
called <InterfaceClass __main__.IBar> ()
>>> class ISpam(zope.interface.Interface): pass
...
>>> ISpam()
Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<console>", line 1, in ?
TypeError: function takes at least 1 argument (0 given)
>>> ISpam.__class__ = InterfaceClass
>>> ISpam()
Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<console>", line 1, in ?
TypeError: function takes at least 1 argument (0 given)
```

items.title: zope.interface raises unhelpful "TypeError: Error when calling the metaclass bases" upon an invalid interface
items.body:
In https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/149544, @kumar303 reports:

> Since it took me so long to debug a traceback that looked like this:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
...
File "/Users/kumar/src/zope.interface/src/zope/interface/advice.py", line 132, in advise
    return callback(newClass)
File "/Users/kumar/src/zope.interface/src/zope/interface/declarations.py", line 485, in _implements_advice
    classImplements(cls, *interfaces)
File "/Users/kumar/src/zope.interface/src/zope/interface/declarations.py", line 462, in classImplements
    spec.declared += tuple(_normalizeargs(interfaces))
File "/Users/kumar/src/zope.interface/src/zope/interface/declarations.py", line 1372, in _normalizeargs
    _normalizeargs(v, output)
File "/Users/kumar/src/zope.interface/src/zope/interface/declarations.py", line 1371, in _normalizeargs
    for v in sequence:
TypeError: Error when calling the metaclass bases
    iteration over non-sequence
```

> I thought I would take 5 minutes and submit a patch for a better error. I don't see any harm in catching the TypeError produced by trying to iterate sequence so this should be safe. If you're wondering what would cause an error like this, just google for "zope.interface TypeError: Error when calling the metaclass bases" ... there are a lot of hits. For a more specific example, this other bug motivated me to write this one :) -- https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope3/+bug/149517

And includes a patch:

> This patch is against trunk, r 80666. It includes a test and didn't break any existing tests.

  https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/149544/+attachment/155306/+files/zope_interface_better_error.patch

items.title: Optimized version of InterfaceBase doesn't use interface's __adapt__
items.body:
In https://bugs.launchpad.net/zope.interface/+bug/98488, Ben Artin reported:

> According to zope.interface documentation, the `__call__` of an interface should use `__adapt__` in the interface to attempt to adapt the object. This is not so with the optimized C version of `InterfaceBase`:

```
from zope.interface import Interface
class Test(Interface):
    pass
def adapt(*args, **kwargs):
    return 17
from new import instancemethod
Test.__adapt__ = instancemethod(adapt, Test)
print Test.__adapt__(1) # prints 17
Test(1) # Generates an exception
```

> This is not how `InterfaceBasePy.__call__` behaves -- it uses `interface.__adapt__`, which can be customized for each interface. This discrepancy between `InterfaceBasePy` and the C-optimized `InterfaceBase` should be eliminated; I believe that the behavior of `InterfaceBase` should change to match that of `InterfaceBasePy`.

@ctheune followed up:

> `__adapt__` is not documented in IInterface. However, the tests say that we do this and respect PEP 246 behaviour.
